facts: There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all of Earth's beaches.
The light from some stars takes millions of years to reach Earth, so we see them as they were in the past.
Stars don't actually twinkle - Earth's atmosphere makes them appear to shimmer.
The Sun is actually a star - the closest one to Earth at 93 million miles away.
Neutron stars are so dense that one teaspoon would weigh 6 billion tons on Earth.
The largest known star, UY Scuti, could fit 5 billion Suns inside it.
New stars are being born every day from clouds of dust and gas called nebulae.
Stars come in different colors based on temperature: red (coolest), yellow, white, blue (hottest).
A star's brightness is called its magnitude, measured on a scale developed 2,000 years ago.
Black holes form when massive stars collapse at the end of their lives.
The North Star (Polaris) has been used for navigation for thousands of years.
Stars are made mostly of hydrogen and helium - the two lightest elements.
Some stars orbit each other in pairs called binary star systems.
Every atom in your body was once inside a star that exploded billions of years ago.
The closest star to our Sun is Proxima Centauri, 4.24 light-years away.
Shooting stars aren't stars at all - they're meteors burning up in Earth's atmosphere.
Ancient civilizations created constellations by connecting stars to tell stories.
Stars produce energy through nuclear fusion, combining hydrogen atoms into helium.
